title: OneRepublic's Ryan Tedder defends the band's lacklustre NRL Grand Final performance
text:
OneRepublic's Ryan Tedder has defended the band's lacklustre NRL Grand Final performance over the weekend.

Appearing in a pre-recorded interview on Sunrise on Wednesday, the American singer and producer said that fans at sporting events don't really care for the music.

The 40-year-old added that the only acts that get support at games are rockers from '30 years ago that wrote the biggest rock song of all time.'

'The only acts that get unilateral love and support is an act from 30 years ago!' OneRepublic's Ryan Tedder defended the band's lacklustre NRL Grand Final performance and said sport fans 'aren't there for the music'

'Those fans are not there for music, they're there to watch their teams crush the hell out of each other,' Ryan said.

He added: 'Doesn't matter what you do.'

'Typically, the only acts that get unilateral love and support at a rugby match is an act from 30 years ago that wrote the biggest rock song of all time.'

Pre-game entertainment: OneRepublic were the opening act for the NRL Grand Final on Sunday

OneRepublic were the opening act for the NRL Grand Final on Sunday.

As the group chose to cover Beyoncé's 2008 hit Halo, viewers took to Twitter to criticise OneRepublic as well as Nine, for the odd song choice.

'Really? A Queen Bey funeral song pre-game?' One viewer commented online.

'Why is Halo being sung as a cover at the NRL Grand Final?' another fan asked.

'Really? A Queen Bey funeral song pre-game?' As the group chose to cover Beyoncé's 2008 hit Halo, viewers took to Twitter to criticise OneRepublic as well as Nine, for the odd song choice

'OneRepublic's screaming cover of Beyoncé's Halo, while the choir try to cover up how bad he's singing, was the perfect choice to get the crowd pumped up for the #NRLGF well done NRL,' one wrote.

However it wasn't all negative, with select viewers praising OneRepublic for a stellar performance.

The band sung Beyoncé's Halo as well as their own hits, Counting Stars and Something I Need.

Tunes: The band sung Beyoncé's Halo as well as their own hits, Counting Stars and Something I Need

Meanwhile, viewers also slammed Nine for failing to broadcast Daryl Braithwaite's NRL Grand Final half-time performance.

Taking to Twitter on Sunday, football fans labelled the network 'an absolute disgrace' after the 70-year-old sang his hit Horses at Sydney's ANZ Stadium.

'Is there anything more un-Australian than not showing us Daryl Braithwaite?' one viewer asked online.
description: OneRepublic's Ryan Tedder has defended the band's lacklustre NRL Grand Final performance.
authors: Kristy Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
